content: The Act titled "DHS Multiyear Acquisition Strategy Act of 2017" introduces a new section on multiyear acquisition strategy in the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The DHS Multiyear Acquisition Strategy Act of 2017 requires the Secretary to submit a multiyear acquisition strategy to congressional committees and the Comptroller General of the United States within 1 year of enactment. The strategy aims to guide Department acquisitions, address evolving threats, and assist industry in aligning resources. The DHS Multiyear Acquisition Strategy Act of 2017 mandates the Secretary to develop a strategy for Department acquisitions, involving consultation with various stakeholders. The strategy must include a prioritized list of major acquisition programs to address security and economic benefits. The DHS Multiyear Acquisition Strategy Act of 2017 requires the Secretary to develop a strategy for Department acquisitions, including a prioritized list of major acquisition programs to address security and economic benefits. The strategy must also include plans for developing a reliable inventory of investments and real property assets, addressing funding gaps, and leveraging best practices to eliminate overpayment for items. The DHS Multiyear Acquisition Strategy Act of 2017 mandates the development of a strategy for Department acquisitions to prioritize major programs, address funding gaps, and leverage best practices to prevent overpayment for items. This includes rationalizing purchases, aligning pricing, utilizing economies of scale, and identifying necessary capabilities to support technology acquisition. The DHS Multiyear Acquisition Strategy Act of 2017 requires the Department to prioritize major programs, address funding gaps, and leverage best practices in acquisitions. It focuses on acquiring appropriate technology, improving mission performance, testing and acquiring innovative solutions, and developing incentives to save taxpayer dollars. The DHS Multiyear Acquisition Strategy Act of 2017 prioritizes major programs, addresses funding gaps, and leverages best practices in acquisitions to avoid schedule delays, achieve cost savings, and minimize cost overruns by improving the acquisition process through various stages. It also focuses on improving outreach and communication with industry, small businesses, and other entities. The Department collaborates with various entities to understand the market for technologies and products to meet its mission needs before acquisition. This includes engaging small and disadvantaged businesses, analyzing their cost-benefit tradeoffs, addressing barriers to entry, and unique requirements. The Department collaborates with small and disadvantaged businesses to understand the market for technologies and products. The acquisition strategy includes a plan for competition and the acquisition workforce. The acquisition strategy includes a plan to ensure competition for major acquisition programs, which may involve measures such as competitive prototyping, dual-sourcing, and periodic competitions for subsystem upgrades. Additionally, the plan includes actions to address long-term competitive effects of program decisions and the acquisition workforce plan. The acquisition workforce plan under this subsection shall address ways to improve the recruitment, hiring, training, and retention of Department acquisition workforce personnel, including contracting officer's representatives, in order to retain highly qualified individuals. The acquisition workforce plan aims to retain highly qualified individuals with experience in acquisition, complex procurements, and program management. It empowers program managers to manage programs accountably and transparently, prevents duplication in training requirements, and aligns with Government-wide standards. The government aims to establish acquisition positions to support Department requirements in program management, systems engineering, procurement, test and evaluation, life cycle logistics, cost estimating, and contracting. This will strengthen contracting performance and align with Government-wide standards. The government aims to establish acquisition positions to support Department requirements in program management, systems engineering, procurement, test and evaluation, life cycle logistics, cost estimating, and contracting. This includes strengthening the performance of contracting officers' representatives by assessing certification and training effectiveness, and increasing training for investigators and auditors to examine fraud in major acquisition programs. The government aims to establish acquisition positions to support Department requirements in program management, systems engineering, procurement, test and evaluation, life cycle logistics, cost estimating, and contracting. This includes identifying opportunities to leverage existing Government and private sector resources in coordination with the Inspector General of the Department. Definitions for "acquisition" and "appropriate congressional committees" are provided in this section. The term 'best practices' in acquisition involves a knowledge-based approach to capability development, including identifying needs, assessing alternatives, establishing requirements, realistic cost assessments, securing funding, demonstrating maturity in technology, design, and manufacturing, and using milestones to show progress. The term 'Component Acquisition Executive' refers to the senior acquisition official within a component designated by the Under Secretary for Management with authority for leading standardized processes and workforce integration in the Department of Homeland Security. The Component Acquisition Executive is responsible for leading acquisition and program management processes to ensure compliance with Federal law and regulations, including overseeing major acquisition programs with significant expenditures. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new item after section 835. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new section, Sec. 836, regarding a multiyear acquisition strategy. The Government Accountability Office will review this strategy. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the first multiyear acquisition strategy under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 within 180 days to assess its effectiveness in complying with requirements, establishing connections between objectives and priorities, reflecting best practices, and ensuring competition for major acquisition programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the first multiyear acquisition strategy under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 within 180 days to assess its effectiveness in complying with requirements, establishing connections between objectives and priorities, reflecting best practices, ensuring competition for major acquisition programs, considering cost savings through existing technologies, preventing duplication in workforce training, and providing incentives for program managers to reduce costs. The Senate committees will receive a report on the review conducted under this section, which may include a classified annex. The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 20, 2017. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
